agent.text: Constantine I reorganized the Roman Empire in the early 4th century, around 324-337 AD. This reorganization included establishing Constantinople as the new capital and legalizing Christianity. Constantine's changes marked a significant shift that set the stage for the development of the Byzantine Empire as a distinct entity from the classical Roman Empire. Constantine moved the seat of the Empire to Constantinople, which he founded as a second Rome on the site of Byzantium, a city strategically located on the trade routes between Europe and Asia and between the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Constantine significantly changed the Empire's military, monetary, civil, and religious institutions.

contexts.text:
Byzantine Empire
Several signal events from the 4th to 6th centuries mark the period of transition during which the Roman Empire 's Greek East and Latin West divided . Constantine I ( r . 324 -- 337 ) reorganised the empire , made Constantinople the new capital , and legalised Christianity . Under Theodosius I ( r . 379 -- 395 ) , Christianity became the Empire 's official state religion and other religious practices were proscribed . Finally , under the reign of Heraclius ( r . 610 -- 641 ) , the Empire 's military and administration were restructured and adopted Greek for official use instead of Latin . Thus , although the Roman state continued and Roman state traditions were maintained , modern historians distinguish Byzantium from ancient Rome insofar as it was centred on Constantinople , oriented towards Greek rather than Latin culture , and characterised by Orthodox Christianity .
contexts.title: Byzantine Empire

|user|: why was the eastern roman empire called the byzantine empire
|assistant|: Modern historians refer to the Byzantine Empire as such to distinguish it from ancient Rome. This name comes from Byzantium, the original name of Constantinople, the capital city of the empire. The citizens of the empire continued to refer to their empire as the Roman Empire or Romania and to themselves as "Romans." 
|user|: What was its religion?
|assistant|: During the reign of Constantine in the Byzantine Empire, Christianity was not declared the exclusive state religion, but it received special favor from the emperor, who granted it generous privileges. Constantine also established the principle that emperors could not unilaterally decide matters of religious doctrine, and instead, they should convene general ecclesiastical councils for that purpose. His summoning of the Synod of Arles and the First Council of Nicaea demonstrated his commitment to the unity of the Church and asserted his authority as its leader.The ascendancy of Christianity was briefly challenged when Emperor Julian came to power in 361 and sought to revive polytheism throughout the empire. He was later known as "Julian the Apostate" by the Church. However, Julian's efforts were reversed when he died in battle in 363.
The foundation of the Byzantine Empire was based on the belief that it was a reflection of the Kingdom of Heaven on Earth. Just as God ruled in Heaven, the Emperor, created in His image, was expected to govern on Earth and uphold His commandments. The empire aspired to be universal and aimed to encompass all the peoples of the Earth. Ideally, all people would be members of the one true Christian Church, the Orthodox Church.

contexts.text:
Byzantine Empire
In 330 , Constantine moved the seat of the Empire to Constantinople , which he founded as a second Rome on the site of Byzantium , a city strategically located on the trade routes between Europe and Asia and between the Mediterranean and the Black Sea . Constantine introduced important changes into the Empire 's military , monetary , civil and religious institutions . As regards his economic policies in particular , he has been accused by certain scholars of `` reckless fiscality '' , but the gold solidus he introduced became a stable currency that transformed the economy and promoted development .
contexts.title: Byzantine Empire
